title: What is the origin of the term 'inverse probability' (Bayesian, terminology, history, statistics)? - Quora

response.answer_text: It's the inverse of “direct probability.” E.g. if I start off by assuming a probabilistic model—like the hypothesis “The coin I'm tossing is fair”—then that assigns a probability to each possible outcome—like “P(heads|fair)=0.5.” That's direct probability. “Inverse probability” goes the other way around—instead of asking for the probability of an outcome given the model, it asks for the probability of (some aspect of) the model given the outcome—like “P(fair|heads)=?” The term itself was first used in 1837 by De Morgan, who was talking about Laplace's development in 1774 of the general form of Bayes' theorem (Bayes himself had only given a special case).
